21.

The kingdom protista does  not include

(1) photosynthetic organisms

(2) flagellate organisms

(3) parasitic organisms

(4) bacteria
Ans. 4
Sol. Protista kingdom was created by Haeckel (1886). It includes all unicellular and colonial eukaryotes except those of green and red algae. Protists were the first eukaryotes to evolve about 1000 million years back. They are mostly aquatic. They are broadly divided into three groups - photosynthetic, slime moulds and protozoans. Photosynthetic protists are photoautotrophic like diatoms, dinoflagellates and euglenoids. Protozoan protists include sarcodines/amoebae, zooflagellates, sporozoans and ciliates. It does not include bacteria. Bacteria are simple prokaryotes, occurring in soil, water and air and as symbionts, parasites and pathogens of animals, plants and other micro-organisms.

24.

With respect to fungal sexual cycle, choose the correct sequence of events.
1.  Karyogamy, Plasmogamy and Meiosis

2.  Meiosis, Plaamogamy and Karyogamy

3.  Plasmogamy, Karyogamy and Meiosis

4.  Meiosis, Karyogamy and Plasmogamy
Ans. 3
Sol. Plasmogamy means fusion of protoplasm and karyogamy means fusion of nucleus. These two events lead to the formation of zygote (2n) which is diploid structure where meiosis takes place.

39.

Which one of the following is considered important in the development of seed habit?

(1) Dependent sporophyte

(2) Heterospory

(3) Haplontic life cycle

(4) Free-living gametophyte
Ans. 2
Sol. Page 38, XI NCERT
Heterospory is the production of spores of two different sizes and of two different developmental patterns. Heterospory is an expression of sex determining spores of the plant. It is the most important evolutionary development in the vascular plants because it has ultimately lead to seed development, eg, Selaginella, Salvinia, Azolla, etc.

40.

The most primitive among the living vascular plants are the

(1) ferns

(2) brown algae

(3) mosses

(4) cycads
Ans. 1
Sol. Page 36, XI NCERT
Ferns belongs to the phylum tracheophyta = tracheata (division pteridophyta of the old system). Plants of this group posses vascular tissue (i.e. xylem and phloem) for the conduction of water, minerals and for translocation of food. They are mostly herbaceous plants which grow in moist and shady places. These are flowerless plants which do not produce seeds. Spores germinate to produce gametophytes, bearing antheridia (male reproductive structures) and archegonia (female reproductive structures).

46.

Consider the following characters:

I. Heterotroph organisms

II. A dikaryon stage

III. Cell wall made of chitin

IV. Undergo nuclear mitosis

Which of the above relate to fungi?

(1) I, II and III

(2) I, III and IV

(3) II, III and IV

(4) I, II, III and IV
Ans. 4
Sol. Page 22-23, XI NCERT
Fungi have nuclear mitosis. Mitosis in fungi is different from that in plants or most other eukaryotes in one key respect: the nuclear envelope does not break down and re-form. Instead, mitosis takes place within the nucleus.

(1) cyanobacteria

(2) archaebacteria

(3) chemosynthetic autotrophs

(4) heterotrophic bacteria
Ans. 4
Sol. Page 19, XI NCERT
Heterotrophic bacteria are most abundant in nature. Many of them have a significant impact on human affairs. These are helpful in making curd from milk (e.g., Lactobacillussp.), production of antibiotics (e.g., Streptomyces sp.) and fixing nitrogen in legume roots (e.g., Rhizobium spe).

57.

In which of the following sets of organisms, does the external fertilization occur?

(1) Echinodermata and mosses

(2) Hemichordata and ferns

(3) Amphibians and algae

(4) Reptiles and gymnosperms
Ans. 3
Sol. Page 57, XI NCERT
When fertilization occurs outside the body of the organism, this type of gametic fusion is called external fertilization or external syngamy. The external medium such as water is required for this type of fertilization. Thus, in most aquatic organisms such as a majority of algae, fishes and amphibians, external fertilization occurs.

71.

Which one of the the following phyla is correctly matched with its two general characteristics?

(1) Arthropoda − Body divided into head, thorax and abdomen and respiration by mouth

(2) Chordata − Notochord at early stage only and separate anal and urinary openings to the outside

(3) Echinodermata − Pentamerous radial symmetry and mostly internal fertilization

(4) Mollusca − Normally oviparous and development through a trochophore or veliger larva
Ans. 4
Sol. Mollusca is normally oviparous and its development may be direct or indirect. If development is indirect then it occurs through trochophore or veliger larva. Arthropoda is the largest phylum of animal kingdom. Body of arthropod is divisible into head, thorax and abdomen. Head and thorax often fused to form cephalothorax. The respiration takes place by general body surface, gills, tracheae or book lungs. Echinoderms have a pentamerous radial symmetry derived from an original bilateral symmetry. The fertilization is external, development indirect through free-swimming larval forms. Chordates are sharply distinguished from non-chordates by presence of notochord, dorsal tubular central nervous system and pharyngeal gills slits.

CHEMISTRY

SECTION A

101.
An electron-deficient compound among the following is -
 
1. (SiH3)2
 
2. (BH3)2
 
3. PH3
 
4. (CH3)2
Ans. 2
Sol.
HINT: Central atom octet is not completed in electron - deficient species.
 
Explanation:

Step 1: (BH3)2 is diborane and it is electron deficient.

Step 2: It has 3c-2e- bonds and it acts as a lewis acid. While other compound like (SiH3)2(SiH3)2, PH3PH3, and (CH3)2(CH3)2 is not electron deficient because its central atom octet is completed.

102.

The number of sigma (σσ) and pi (ππ) bonds in pent-2-en-4-yne is-

1.  13 σσ bonds and no ππ bond.

2.  10 σσ bonds and 3 ππ bonds.

3.  8 σσ bonds and 5 ππ bonds.

4.  11 σσ bonds and 2 ππ bonds.
Ans. 2
Sol.

HINT: Molecule contains one double bond and one triple bond.

Explanation:

Single bond represents sigma bond, double bond represents one sigma and one ππ bond. Triple bond represents one sigma and two ππ bonds

The structure of pent-2-en-4-yne is as follows:

CH3−CH=CH−C≡C−H(10 σ & 3 π)CH3-CH=CH-C≡C-H10 σ & 3 π

The molecule contains total 10 sigma bonds and 3 ππ bonds.

103.

Most covalent compound among the following is :

1. AlF3

2. AlCl3

3. AlBr3

4. AlI3
Ans. 4
Sol.
HINT: Use the concept of Fajan's Rule
 
Explanation:

STEP 1: For most covalent compound - 

1. Cation should be smaller.

2. Charge on cation should be high.

3. EA/EN of nonmetal should be low.

STEP 2: 

The electronegativity difference between Al and IAl and I is minimum thus it is most covalent.

104.

The favorable factors for the formation of an ionic bond would be -

1. Low ionization enthalpy, High electron gain enthalpy, High lattice energy.

2. High ionization enthalpy, High electron gain enthalpy, High lattice energy.

3. Low ionization enthalpy, Low electron gain enthalpy, Low lattice energy.

4. High ionization enthalpy, Low electron gain enthalpy, High lattice energy.
Ans. 1
Sol.
HINT: Ionic bonding involves the complete transfer of valence electron(s) between atoms.
 
Explanation:

The formation of ionic bonds depends upon the ease with which neutral atoms can lose or gain electrons. The bond formation also depends upon the lattice energy of the compound formed.

Hence, favorable factors for ionic bond formation are as follows:

(i) Low ionization enthalpy of the metal atom.

(ii) High electron gain enthalpy (Δeg H)∆eg H of a non-metal atom.

(iii) High lattice energy of the compound formed.

105.

The incorrect order for the given properties is:

1. AlF3>MgO>MgF2AlF3>MgO>MgF2    : Lattice energy

2. Li>Na>Al>MgLi>Na>Al>Mg       : Electron affinity

3. PF5> SF6 > SiF4PF5> SF6 > SiF4    : Lewis acidic character

4. SiCl4>SiBr4 >SiI4SiCl4>SiBr4 >SiI4   : Decreasing ionic character
Ans. 3
Sol.
HINT: Lattice energy depends on the product of ionic charges.
 
Explanation:
 
1. In the first option, the q1 and q2q1 and q2 factor increases, thus, lattice energy increases.
2. The 2nd option is correct because, due to completely filled 3s subshell, Mg does not have tendency to accept an electron.
Electron affinity values  of Li = 0.618 eV, Na = 0.547 eV , Mg = -0.4 eV and Al = 0.432 eV

3. The correct order of lewis acidic character: PF5>SiF4>SF6PF5>SiF4>SF6 Although, S has vacant 3d-orbitals it cannot accept co-ordinate bonds from Lewis base due to the steric crowding factor as S-atom is already bonded to six F-atoms.

4. According to Fajan's rule : Anion should be small for more ionic character.

So , the order of ionic character is : SiCl4>SiBr4 >SiI4SiCl4>SiBr4 >SiI4

106.

Incorrect statement regarding resonating structures is : 

1. The contributing structure must have the same number of unpaired electrons.

2. The contributing structures should have similar energies.

3. The resonance hybrid should have higher energy than any of the contributing structures.

4. None of the above.
Ans. 3
Sol.

HINT:  The resonance hybrid should have lower energy than any of the contributing structure.

Explanation:

Conditions of resonance are: 

1. The relative position of all the atoms must be same in each resonating structures.

2. Number of paired and unpaired electrons in each resonating structure must be same so that there is a continuous change from one bond type to another bond  type may occur.

3. Contributing structures should have almost equal energy .

4. Like charges should be greatly separated and unlikely charges should be placed together.

5. The more electropositive element should preferably have a positive charge and more electronegative element should have a negative .
 
6. The resonance hybrid should have lower energy than any of the contributing structure.

107.

H2OH2O has a net dipole moment while BeF2BeF2 has zero dipole moment because :

1. F is more electronegative than oxygen.

2. Be is more electronegative than oxygen. 

3. H2O H2O  molecule is linear and BeF2BeF2 is bent.

4. BeF2BeF2 molecule is linear and H2OH2O is bent.
Ans. 4
Sol.

HINT : Dipole moment depends on the structure of the compound.

Explanation:

The structure of H2OH2O and BeF2F2 is given below:

 

Due to the presence of lone pair around a central atom H2OH2O is polar and it has a dipole moment. BeF2F2 is linear and its net dipole moment is zero.

Presence of lone pair around central atom creates polarity.

108.

The correct increasing order of the polarizing power of the cationic species  K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Be2+K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Be2+is: 

1. Be2+<K+<Ca2+<Mg2+Be2+<K+<Ca2+<Mg2+

2. K+<Ca2+<Mg2+<Be2+K+<Ca2+<Mg2+<Be2+

3. Ca2+<Mg2+<Be2+<K+Ca2+<Mg2+<Be2+<K+

4. Mg2+<Be2+<K+<Ca2+Mg2+<Be2+<K+<Ca2+
Ans. 2
Sol.

HINT: Charge/size ratio is inversely proportional to the size of cation.

Explanation:

STEP 1: 

Polarizing power refers to an atoms ability to pull an electron toward it, polarizing the atom the electron comes from. Since cations are positive, they are able to attract electrons toward themselves.

STEP 2:

The increasing order of cation size is :

K+K+>Ca2+Ca2+> Mg2+Mg2+> Be2+Be2+

So, its reverse order is applied for the charge size ratio. Higher is the charge/size ratio, more is the polarizing power i.e.., 

K+ < Ca2+ < Mg2+ < Be2+K+ < Ca2+ < Mg2+ < Be2+

A species among the following having a triangular planar shape is -

1. N3-    

2. NO3- 

3. NO2-

4. CO2
Ans. 2
Sol.
HINT: The trigonal planar geometry is same as plane triangular shape.
 
Explanation:

Species with sp2sp2 hybridized central atom are plane triangular in shape. Among the given species NO3- and NO2- is sp2 hybridized with no lone pair and 1 lone pair of electrons on the central atom respectively.

The shape of NO2- is bent and the shape of NO3-  is trigonal planar, whereas, N3, and CO2 are sp hybridized with a linear shape.

111.

Which of the following is paramagnetic?

1. CO               

2. O−2O2-

3. CN-               

4. NO+
Ans. 2
Sol.

HINT: Paramagnetic species contains unpaired electrons in their molecular orbital electronic configuration.

Explanation:

Molecular orbital configuration of the given species is given as :

 CO (6+8=14) = σ1s2, σ∗1s2, σ2s2, σ∗2s2, π2p2x≈π2p2y, σ2p2zσ1s2, σ1s2*, σ2s2, σ2s2*, π2px2≈π2py2, σ2pz2

(All the electrons are paired so it is diamagnetic)

 Electronic configuration of O−2O2-(8+8+1=17) = σ1s2, σ∗1s2, σ2s2, σ∗2s2,σ2p2z, π2p2x≈π2p2y, π∗2p2x≈π∗2p1yσ1s2, σ1s2*, σ2s2, σ2s2*,σ2pz2, π2px2≈π2py2, π2px2*≈π2py1*

This contains a unpaired electorn. So, O−2O2- is paramagnetic in nature.

112.

The strongest hydrogen bond present among the following is-

1. O—H‐‐‐SO—H‐‐‐S

2. S—H‐‐‐OS—H‐‐‐O

3. F—H‐‐‐FF—H‐‐‐F

4. F—H‐‐‐OF—H‐‐‐O
Ans. 3
Sol.

HINT: HF has the strongest H-bonding

Explanation:

 H—H—bonding order: ‐‐‐H—F >‐‐‐H—O>‐‐‐H—N‐‐‐H—F >‐‐‐H—O>‐‐‐H—N

The strongest hydrogen bond is in hydrogen fluoride because the power of the hydrogen bond is directly proportional to the electronegativity of the atom. The electronegativity ∝ 1/atomic size.electronegativity ∝ 1/atomic size.

So, fluorine has maximum electronegativity and minimum atomic size. 

Hence, it can show maximum hydrogen bonding.

3. Na2S > CuS > ZnS

4. Na2S > ZnS > CuS
Ans. 4
Sol.

HINT: Ionic compounds are more soluble in water or in an aqueous medium.

Explanation:

Ionic character ∝∝size of cation (if anion is same)

The order of size of cation is:   Na+ > Zn2+ > Cu2+

... The order of ionic character and hence of solubility in water is as

                    Na2S > ZnS > CuS

The partial pressure of oxygen in a flask containing 16 g O2O2 and 32 g SO2SO2 is-

1. 1/16 of total pressure

2. 1/2 of total pressure

3. 2/3 of total pressure

4. None of the above
Ans. 2
Sol.

Hint: P=PTXgasP=PTXgas

Explanation:

Step 1:

Calculate the number of moles is as follows:

Number of moles of O2=1632=0.5 mole O2=1632=0.5 mole 

Number of a mole of SO2=3264= 0.5 mole SO2=3264= 0.5 mole 

Step 2:

Calculate the partial pressure of O2O2 as follows:

P=PTXgasP=PTXgas

The partial pressure of O2=0.51.0×total pressureO2=0.51.0×total pressure

=12=12 of total pressure 

Hence, the partial pressure of oxygen is 1/2 of total pressure.

SECTION B

136.

An amphiprotic (can accept and give proton) ion is-

1. HPO−3HPO3-

2. H2PO−2H2PO2-

3. H3PO4H3PO4

4. H2PO−4H2PO4-
Ans. 4
Sol.

Hint: Accept and give up a proton.

An amphiprotic substance can both donate or accept a proton.

HPO−3HPO3- is a conjugate base of H2PO3H2PO3. It has only one acidic hydrogen. Thus, HPO−3HPO3- can only act as a base, not an acid.

H2PO−2H2PO2- is a conjugate base of H3PO2H3PO2. It has only one acidic hydrogen. Thus, H2PO−2H2PO2-  can only act as a base, not an acid.

H3PO4H3PO4 is an acid not a base.

Only H2PO−4H2PO4- is it an amphiprotic substance because it can acts as an acid as well as a base also.

H2PO−4H2PO4- can acts as base and form H3PO4H3PO4. It can act as an acid and form HPO2−4HPO42-

mg−2μmg=3maa=g[1−2μ]3mg−2μmg=3maa=g[1−2μ]3

(2) Change in gravitational potential energy

= Elastic potential energy stored in compressed spring 

⇒mg(h+x)=12kx2⇒mg(h+x)=12kx2

2.  50

3.  40

4.  20

Sol.

ω0=1200×2π60=40π rad/sω0=1200×2π60=40π rad/s
 
Step 2: Find the angular retardation

Step 4: Find the number of revolutions before stopping.
 
No. of revolutions = θ2π=100θ2π=100

3. ω(M+2m)Mω(M+2m)M

Ans. 2
Sol.

As given in the question that the two objects of equal masses m are attached to the opposite ends of the diameter of the ring of mass M and the radius R, then angular momentum will be conserved. According to which we can write: 
I1ω1=I2ω2⇒MR2ω=(MR2+2mR2)ω2⇒ω2=MR2ω(M+2m)R2=MωM+2mI1ω1=I2ω2⇒MR2ω=MR2+2mR2ω2⇒ω2=MR2ωM+2mR2=MωM+2m

181.

If the sun and the planets carried huge amounts of opposite charges,

(a) all three of Kepler’s laws would still be valid

(b) only the third law will be valid

(c) the second law will not change

(d) the first law will still be valid

(1) (a, b, c)

(2) (a, d)

(3) (b, c, d)

(4) (a, c, d)
Ans. 4
Sol.
(4) Hint: The motion of the planets depends on the nature of the forces acting on the planets.
Step 1: Find the nature of the forces acting on the Earth.
Due to huge amounts of opposite charges on the sun and the earth, the electrostatic force of attraction will be large. Gravitational force is also attractive in nature. Hence both the forces will be added. Both the forces obey inverse square law and are central forces. As both the forces are of the same nature, hence all three of Kepler's laws will be valid.

1. √22

2. 1√212

3. 1313

4. 1212
Ans. 2
Sol.

If the energy in the form of kinetic energy which is equal to binding energy, is supplied to the sphere, it leaves the gravitational field of the earth. 
At a platform at a height of h, 
Escape energy = binding energy of the sphere 
Or 12mve'2=GMmR+h12mve'2=GMmR+h 
Or ve'=√2GMR+h=√2GM2R  (∵h=R)ve'=2GMR+h=2GM2R  (∵h=R) 
But at the surface of the earth, 
ve = √2GMR2GMR 
As given, ve'=fveve'=fve 
Hence, √2GM2R2GM2R = f√2GMR2GMR 
 
∴∴ f =1√212
